video.title: The End is Nigh and Yonder: The Cloud Catcher Chronicles (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text:
You know, in this age of fearmongering, populist
takeover, increasing class divide and Ed Sheeran

cameos on Game of Thrones, a lot of people
seem to take comfort in the fact that a mushroom

cloud will probably drop soon and burn our
eyes out while the radiation agonisingly dissolves
us from the inside out.

Well, it&#39;s a lovely fantasy, millennials,
but sadly we&#39;re an infuriatingly adaptable

bunch and if nuclear firestorm couldn&#39;t save
us from the Bay City Rollers it&#39;s not going

to save you from (discreetly Googles current
Billboard top 40) Imagine Dragons.

You&#39;re probably just going to have to tough
it out, but in the meantime, there&#39;s no harm

in a bit of wholesome escapism with Edmund
McMillen&#39;s new game, The End Is Nigh.

Edmund McMillen is a game designer forged
in the old 2000&#39;s Newgrounds flash game era

when everyone was learning that lack of censorship
plus extremely low barrier for entry equals

an awful lot of super violent poorly drawn
cartoon games and animations about poo.

McMillen stood out by making such games as
Super Meat Boy and the Binding of Isaac, actually

quite well designed super violent cartoon
games about poo.

McMillen&#39;s hallmarks besides poo include high
difficulty, a simplistic but highly animated

art style mainly centred around squashy blobs
of flesh, an obvious enthusiasm for retro

video games and a grandiose, apocalyptic sort
of theme, so the End is Nigh represents all

of his squishy blood-leaking poo monsters
coming home to roost, so to speak.

It begins with a squashy blob of flesh playing
retro video games before realising he has

to travel out into the grandiose, apocalyptic
world to make things highly difficult for
himself.

The game is a 2D platformer with much of Super
Meat Boy about it, except slower-paced and

is theoretically an open world as opposed
to Meat Boy&#39;s level-based structure.

In practise, though, each room is an individual
challenge and there&#39;s not much point in coming

back to each one once you have the bandage,
I mean, tumour, so it might as well have been
level based for all it mattered.

Well, I suppose you might want to come back
if you get off on watching water balloons

full of gravy explode, but there are plenty
of places where you can enjoy that particular

spectacle, such as every square inch of the
fucking game.

Hey, look at me, world, I&#39;m about to say that
this high difficulty game is too hard.

That&#39;s right, now you have a whole brain cell
dedicated to me saying that and you&#39;ll never
get it back.

Yeah, genius, it&#39;s supposed to be hard, but
a slower ramp up would be nice.
Difficulty curve, not difficulty wall.

Not difficulty overhang, slick with eagle
jizz.

Feels like every time a new element is introduced,
it&#39;s demonstrated precisely once and then

we&#39;re immediately called upon to pixel-perfect
tootsie jump off it with the exact timing

necessary to miss a gargoyle&#39;s deadly swinging
bellend piercing by one eighth of an inch.

And if that&#39;s what you want, then I can recommend
the End is Nigh, as well as possibly hiring

a therapist to work through your self-destructive
urges.

I like hard games, you know that, but The
End Is Nigh just isn&#39;t grabbing me and I think

it&#39;s because I don&#39;t get a sense that there&#39;ll
be any reward for putting myself through the
trials.

I repeatedly pound my testicles with a hammer
because I&#39;m trying to save money on a vasectomy,
not just for the sake of it.

Super Meat Boy had stuff to unlock, a squashy
flesh blob princess to save, a dizzying array

of secret extras, a lively air of fun and
a varied palette of blood reds and poo browns,

and End is Nigh just feels like Super Meat
Boy with none of any of that.
Your only reward is more, harder challenges.
Fucking hell.
At least Sisyphus was getting regular exercise.

In brief, I don&#39;t think The End Is Nigh has
enough going on.

I turn on, it goes &quot;Hello, everything&#39;s gone
to shit.

I&#39;m shit, you&#39;re shit, the world is shit,
why don&#39;t you come outside and see how shit

it is and will continue to be whatever you
do.&quot;

And then I turn off the TV news and play the
End is Nigh instead, which gives a very similar

vibe, and I don&#39;t feel particularly motivated
to stick with it.

I&#39;m not saying it needs to promise me chocolate
buttons and snuggles under a rainbow, just

something other than more opportunities to
get remorselessly pounded like I&#39;m a turd
it&#39;s trying to stomp through a shower drain.

Moving on, I thought I&#39;d better play something
from the opposite end of the open world spectrum

as well this week, if only to stave off the
voices, and Steam obligingly belched up the

rather ungainly titled Yonder: The Cloud Catcher
Chronicles.

An open world crafty explorey hoardy timewastey
ooh nicey strokey animals game.

The vibe I was getting from it was Harvest
Moon by way of Zelda: Breath of the Wild - build

a farm inside a freely explorable sandbox
world, and help lots of people who are all

perfectly alright except they&#39;re missing five
moose scrotums for their husband&#39;s sausage
factory.

Also the art style reminded me of a Playmobil
pirate ship I used to have as a kid, especially

at the beginning when you&#39;re on a pirate ship,
although thankfully this one didn&#39;t have the

springloaded cannons with the projectiles
that get lost in the carpet for the guinea
pig to one day choke to death on.

A ship in an intro sequence to a fantasy exploration
game is of course equivalent to a helicopter

in the intro of an action game, so naturally
it&#39;s wrecked for no adequate reason and we&#39;re
deposited on a beach to start our quest.

What was our quest again, Yonder: The Cow
Tipper Chronicles?
Uhhhhhhhhh.
Pick up some stuff.
Anything else?
Uhhhhhh.
Talk to those guys?

I talked to those guys, Yonder, and they told
me to pick up some stuff.
Well there you go, then.

I think the key phrase that sums up the Yonder
experience is &quot;What the fuck am I supposed
to do with this?&quot;

It is the final destination for every path
you can take.

You explore the island, find a hidden ore
vein in a cave, mine it for copper, then you
have some copper.
What the fuck am I supposed to do with this?

Oh look, a place where I can build a bridge
if I bring it twenty sticks, ten vines and
a tube of Pritt Stick.

It leads me to an island with a treasure chest
containing a vajazzling kit.
What the fuck am I supposed to do with this?

I think we&#39;re supposed to be setting up farms,
so we search the land and find the places

where farms can be built, and build farms
on them.
What the fuck am I - WAIT!

Now we can find a wild cow, wave a Curly Wurly
under its nose and lead it back to the farm
to make it your cow.
Okay, what the f- tatatatata!

Now find an NPC whose face you particularly
don&#39;t like and you&#39;d like to see go away,

feed them the entire contents of your fridge
and they&#39;ll go off and run your farm for you.

There, you see, now you&#39;ve got free milk coming
out of the farm whenever you want it.

And, what the fuck am I supposed to do with
that?

Look, if you like direction so much maybe
we could get you a fucking kaleidoscope.

As far as I can tell, Yonder is a game about
becoming the island&#39;s random crap baron on

the off chance that some of the random crap
will be required for one of the many fetch

quests or crafting recipes that result in
you having even more random crap.

You can&#39;t even sell the random crap because
the shops will only exchange it for different

random crap, it&#39;s like dealing in fucking
bitcoins.

Honestly, though, Yonder&#39;s main fault is a
failure to commit.

Either do the free exploration scavenger hunt
OR the farming sim &#39;cos they don&#39;t mix well.

One is about constantly moving on and the
other sitting in one place, behind a cow,

elbow deep in colon like the sorter at a punctuation
factory.
